subsection.title: Basic number concepts
subsection.p: Before we start, we need to formally define some basic concepts of numbers.

statement.p: A number n is said to be even if it is a multiple of 2. That is, if there exists an integer k such that n = 2k, then n is even.

ol.li: 6 is even since 6 = 2\cdot 3
0 is even, since 0 = 2\cdot 0
-8 is even, since -8 = 2 \cdot (-4)
9 is not even, since there is no integer k such that 9=2k

statement.p: A number n is said to be odd if it is not a multiple of 2. That is, if there exists an integer k such that n = 2k + 1, then n is odd.

ol.li: 7 is odd since 7 = 2\cdot 3 + 1
-1 is odd, since -1 = 2\cdot (-1) + 1
8 is not odd, since there is no integer k such that 8=2k+1

statement.p: A number n is said to be rational if there exist integers a, b with b \not=0 such that n = \dfrac{a}{b}. If a number is not rational, we say that it is is irrational.

ol.li: 7 is rational since 7 = \frac71
\frac12 is rational, since both 1 and 2 are integers

ul.li: A theorem is a statement can be shown to be true. We generally reserve the word theorem for an important statement.
A proposition is a less important theorem.
The tools we use to prove a theorem are axioms (or postulates) which are basic assumptions we make, as well as other theorems we've already proven.
A less important theorem that will be helpful in proving others is called a lemma.
A corollary is a theorem that follows directly from a theorem just proved.
A conjecture is a statement that we think my be true (our intuition suggests it)

statement.p: Here's a proposition: If n is an odd integer, then n^2 is odd.
This statement means for the universe of discourse of all integers: \forall n ((n \text{ is odd } ) \to (n^2 \text{ is odd }))
The universe of discourse was implied in the general statement above. Mathematical propositions will almost always omit the words for all.

subsection.title: Direct Proof
subsection.p: A direct proof is used when proving a proposition of the form p \to q. The goal is to show q is true when we assume p is true. Here's the model:

statement.p: Prove that the sum of two odd numbers is even.
Prove that if n is even, then n^2 is even.
Prove that if m+n and n + p are even integers, then m+p is even.

introduction.p: We still want to show a statement is true, but perhaps that's difficult to approach directly. There are several different indirect proofs. The most frequent indirect approaches are proofs by contraposition and proofs by contradication.

subsubsection.title: Proof by Contraposition
subsubsection.p: . A proof by contraposition is a direct proof of \neg q \to \neg p. Here's the model:

proof.p: Show \neg p is true. Therefore, p \to q is true by contraposition.

subsubsection.p: Remember that \neg q \to \neg p \equiv p \to q, so this is a valid argument.

statement.p: Show that if n is an integer and n^3 + 5 is odd, then n is even.
Prove that if n^2 is even, then n is even.

subsubsection.title: Proof by Contradiction
subsubsection.p:

proof.p: Assume, to the contrary, that p is false, that is \neg p is true.
Arrive at a logical contradiction. Some impossibility. Therefore, p is true by contradiction.

subsection.title: Existence Proofs
subsection.p: The claim of an existence theorem is that there is some object that has a property. A constructive proof is one which, during the argumentation, tells the reader specifically how to come up with the object in question. A nonconstructive proof merely confirms the existence of an object, but doesn't give any detail as to how to find it.

statement.p: Prove that either 2 \cdot 10^{500} + 15 or 2 \cdot 10^{500} + 16 is not a perfect square.

hint.p: Let me get you started on it, and we can discuss below. Notice that the two numbers are one apart from eachother. They're massive, so we don't necessarily know whether they're square, but we need only show that not more than one of them is square.
Let's imagine that I have a square number, namely n^2. Is it possible that n^2 - 1 or n^2 + 1 is also a square number? What condition on n is required?

statement.p: Show that between any two rational numbers is another rational number.

hint.p: If we have two rational numbers a/b and c/d with a, b, c, d \in \Z and b, d \ne 0, then we can construct \frac{a+c}{b+d}. Show that this is a rational number which is contained between the two original numbers.

subsection.title: Uniqueness proofs
subsection.p:
The claim of a uniqueness theorem is that there exists an element that has a desired property, and that no other element has this property. The outline of our proof is often:
Prove the existence of x, some element that has the property we want.
Assume that a second element, y also has that property.
Conclude that x = y

statement.p: Show that if a, b, c are real numbers with a\ne 0, then there is a unique solution to the algebraic equation ax+b=c.

hint.p: You know how to solve an algebraic equation. Now assume there's a second solution. Show that the two solutions are equal.

statement.p: Show that if n is an odd integer, then there exists a unique integer k such that n = (k-2) + (k+3)

hint.p: Similar to above, show that k satifies this equation, and then show that if you have another number, say l that also does, it must be the case that k = l.

definition.p:
A vacuous statement is one that is true because the hypothesis is false. You can prove a statement is true immediately.
If I play in the Super Bowl, I will throw the game winning touchdown.
Since I won't ever play in the Super Bowl, it doesn't matter what the truth value of the touchdown statement is. F\to T \equiv T and F \to F \equiv T just the same.

If we know that the conclusion of a statement is true, then the statement has a trivial proof.
Let P(x) be the statement If x\in \mathbb{R} and x \gt 0 , then x^2 + 1 \ge 0.
Since we know that x^2 \ge 0 for any real number, x^2 + 1 \ge x^2 \ge 0. We didn't need the hypothesis x \gt 0. This is a trivial proof.

subsection.title: Counterexamples Revisited
subsection.p: Recall in math propositions, the universal quantifier is implied and is usually omitted. To show a statement is false, we need only find a single counterexample.

statement.p: Each of the following statements is false. Find a specific counterexample and explain why the statement is false.

ol.li: If n is a real number, then (n+4)^2 = n^2 + 16.
Every integer is the sum of the squares of two integers.
\forall x \forall y (x^2 = y^2 \to x = y) where the domain of all variables is the set of all integers.
The product of two irrational numbers is irrational.
The sum of two irrational numbers is irrational.
For example, n = 1 works, since (1+4)^2 = 25 \ne 17 = 1+16.
The number 7 isn't the sum of two squares. The only squares smaller than 7 are 1 and 4. They don't add to 7.
Choosing x= -1 \and y = =1 we have (-1)^2 = (1)^2 but certainly -1 \ne 1.
We know (from above) that \sqrt{2} is irrational. Multiply it by itself. You get 2 which is rational.
Consider a = \sqrt{2} and b=-\sqrt{2}. Then their sum, a+b = 0, which is rational.

For all integers a and b, if a and b are even, then a+b is even.
There are numbers a and b such that a+b is even but a and b are not both even.
False. For example, a = 3 and b = 5. a+b = 8, but neither a nor b are even.
False, since it is equivalent to the original statement.
True. Let a and b be integers. Assume both are even. Then a = 2k and b = 2j for some integers k and j. But then a+b = 2k + 2j = 2(k+j) which is even.

statement.p:
Consider the statement: for all integers n, if n is even then 8n is even.
Prove the statement. What sort of proof are you using?
Is the converse true? Prove or disprove.

li.p:
Direct proof.
Let n be an integer. Assume n is even. Then n = 2k for some integer k. Thus 8n = 16k = 2(8k). Therefore 8n is even.
The converse is false. That is, there is an integer n such that 8n is even but n is odd. For example, consider n = 3. Then 8n = 24 which is even but n = 3 is odd.

statement.p: Your friend has shown you a proof he wrote to show that 1 = 3. Here is the proof:

proof.p: I claim that 1 = 3. Of course we can do anything to one side of an equation as long as we also do it to the other side. So subtract 2 from both sides. This gives -1 = 1. Now square both sides, to get 1 = 1. And we all agree this is true.

statement.p: What is going on here? Is your friend's argument valid? Is the argument a proof of the claim 1=3? Carefully explain using what we know about logic.

hint.p: Hint: What implication follows from the given proof?

statement.p: Suppose that you would like to prove the following implication:

blockquote.p: For all numbers n, if n is prime then n is solitary.

statement.p:
Write out the beginning and end of the argument if you were to prove the statement,
Directly
By contrapositive
By contradiction

You do not need to provide details for the proofs (since you do not know what solitary means). However, make sure that you provide the first few and last few lines of the proofs so that we can see that logical structure you would follow.

ol.li: Assume that n is a prime number. \dots Therefore n is solitary.
Assume that n is not solitary. \dots Therefore n is a prime number by contraposition.
Assume that n is a prime number and is not solitary. \dots This contradicts our assumption. Thus if n is a prime number, n is solitary.

statement.p:
For each of the statements below, say what method of proof you should use to prove them. Then say how the proof starts and how it ends. Pretend bonus points for filling in the middle.
There are no integers x and y such that x is a prime greater than 5 and x = 6y + 3.
For all integers n, if n is a multiple of 3, then n can be written as the sum of consecutive integers.
For all integers a and b, if a^2 + b^2 is odd, then a or b is odd.

li.p: Proof by contradiction. Start of proof: Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that there are integers x and y such that x is a prime greater than 5 and x = 6y + 3. End of proof: this is a contradiction, so there are no such integers.
Direct proof. Start of proof: Let n be an integer. Assume n is a multiple of 3. End of proof: Therefore n can be written as the sum of consecutive integers.
Proof by contrapositive. Start of proof: Let a and b be integers. Assume that a and b are even. End of proof: Therefore a^2 + b^2 is even.

statement.p: Prove that if n^2 is multiple of three, then n is a multiple of three where n is an integer.

hint.p: If a number isn't a multiple of three, then it's either 1 more than a multiple of three or 2 more than a multiple of three, that is, you'll have two cases, either n=3k+1 or 3k+2.

statement.p: Proof by contraposition: Assume that n is not a multiple of three. Then:

Case 1: There exists an integer k such that n = 3k+1. Consider:
n^2 \amp= (3k+1)^2 \amp= 9k^2 + 6k + 1 \amp= 3(3k^2 + 2k) + 1
Hence n^2 is not a mulitple of three.

Case 1: There exists an integer l such that n = 3l+2. Consider:
n^2 \amp= (3l+2)^2 \amp= 9l^2 + 12l + 4 \amp= 9l^2 + 12l + 3 + 1 \amp= 3(3l^2 + 4l + 1) + 1
Hence n^2 is not a mulitple of three.
Thus, we have proven that if n^2 is a multiple of three, then n is a multiple of three by contraposition.

statement.p:
Consider the statement: for all integers a and b, if a is even and b is a multiple of 3, then ab is a multiple of 6.
Prove the statement. What sort of proof are you using?
State the converse. Is it true? Prove or disprove.
(this is a direct proof): Assume that a is even b is a multiple of three. Then there exist integers k and l such that a=2k and b=3l. Then ab = (2k)(3l) = 6kl. Thus ab is a multiple of six.

li.p: The converse is If ab is a multiple of six, then a is even and b is a multiple of three.
This is false. For example, ab = 6 where a = 6 and b=1.

statement.p: Prove the statement: For all integers n, if 5n is odd, then n is odd. Clearly state the style of proof you are using.

solution.p: We will prove the contrapositive: if n is even, then 5n is even.

proof.p: Let n be an arbitrary integer, and suppose n is even. Then n = 2k for some integer k. Thus 5n = 5\cdot 2k = 10k = 2(5k). Since 5k is an integer, we see that 5n must be even. This completes the proof.

statement.p: Prove: x=y if and only if xy=\dfrac{(x+y)^2}{4}. Note, you will need to prove two directions here: the if and the only if part.

\leftarrow Assume that \dfrac{(x+y)^2}{4} = xy Then:
\dfrac{(x+y)^2}{4} \amp= xy (x+y)^2 \amp= 4xy x^2 + 2xy + y^2 \amp= 4xy x^2 - 2xy + y^2 \amp= 0 (x-y)^2 \amp= 0 x \amp = y
This shows that if xy=\dfrac{(x+y)^2}{4}, then x=y.
Prove that \log(7) is irrational.

solution.p: We give a proof by contradiction.

proof.p:
Suppose, contrary to stipulation that \log(7) is rational. Then \log(7) = \frac{a}{b} with a and b \ne 0 integers. By properties of logarithms, this implies
7 = 10^{\frac{a}{b}}
But this is impossible as any power of 7 will be odd while any power of 10 will be even. Therefore, \log(7) is irrational.

statement.p:
Let's say you are presented with a conditional statement p \to q that you want to prove by contradiction. This exercise has you structure a model for contradiction of conditional statements like we saw in the model.
What is your assumption?
What is your conclusion?

ol.li: Assume, to the contrary that p\to q is false, that is, we assume that \neg p\to q or p \land \neg q.
Therefore, p\to q is true by contradiction.

statement.p: Prove that for all integers a, b, and c, if a^2 + b^2 = c^2, then a or b is even.

solution.p: The negation of the statement is a^2 + b^2 = c^2 and both a and b are odd.

statement.p: Assume that a and b are both odd and that a^2 +b^2 = c^2. Then there exist integers k and l such that a=2k+1 and b=2k+1.

First, we observe that
a^2 + b^2 \amp= (2k+1)^2 + (2l+1)^2 \amp = 4k^2 + 4k + 1 + 4l^2 + 4l + 1 \amp = 4k^2 + 4k + 4l^2 + 4l + 2
so that c^2 and hence c is even. Let c=2m where m is some integer. Then:
c^2 \amp = a^2 + b^2 (2k)^2 \amp = 4k^2 + 4k + 4l^2 + 4l + 2 4k^2 \amp = 4(k^2 + k + l^2 + l) + 2
This is a contradiction as we have a multiple of four being equal to something which is not a multiple of four. Thus, our original assumption was incorrect and therefore if a^2 + b^2 = c^2, we conclude that one of a or b is even.
Prove that there are no integer solutions to the equation x^2 = 4y + 3.

Assume, to the contrary, that there is an integer solution, (a, b), to the equation x^2 = 4y + 3 We'll split this into four cases:
Case 1: x is odd and y is even. Then there exist integers k and l such that x=2k+1 and y = 2l. Plugging this into the equation, we have:
x^2 \amp= 4y +3 (2k+1)^2 \amp= 4(2l) +3 4k^2 + 4k + 1 \amp= 8l +3 4k^2 + 4k - 8l \amp= 2 4(k^2 + k - 2l) \amp= 2
This is not possible, as 2 is not a multiple of 4.
Case 2: x is even and y is odd. Then there exist integers k and l such that x=2k and y = 2l+1. Plugging this into the equation, we have:
x^2 \amp= 4y +3 (2k)^2 \amp= 4(2l+1) +3 4k^2 \amp= 8l +4 +3 4k^2 - 8l \amp= 7 4(k^2 - 2l) \amp= 7
This is not possible, as 7 is not a multiple of 4.
Case 3: x and y are both even. Then there exist integers k and l such that x=2k and y = 2l. Plugging this into the equation, we have:
x^2 \amp= 4y +3 (2k)^2 \amp= 4(2l) +3 4k^2 \amp= 8l +3 4k^2 - 8l \amp= 3 4(k^2 - 2l) \amp= 3
This is not possible, as 3 is not a multiple of 4.
Case 4: x and y are both odd. Then there exist integers k and l such that x=2k and y = 2l. Plugging this into the equation, we have:
x^2 \amp= 4y +3 (2k+1)^2 \amp= 4(2l+1) +3 4k^2 +4k + 1\amp= 8l + 4 +3 4k^2 +4k - 8l \amp= 6 4(k^2 +k - 2l) \amp= 6
This is also not possible, as 6 is not a multiple of 4.
Since we've exhausted every possible combination of integer solutions, we conclude that there is no integer solution to the equation x^2 = 4y+3.
